utterances: So, you chose to help.
You chose to help them get across the border.
What did you do?
Well, there was a roadblock north of the town in Mexico.
You could take them through the lower level roadblocks.
We did that with - on a couple runs with the underground railroad.
But these were federal guides.
They look really hairy.
So I charted a route around the roadblock on dirt roads through the Sierra Madre.
The problem was, you put them on the old rickety panel wagon, we went off to look for the dirt roads; the map lied, there were no roads.
So I ended up driving up this arroyo for miles.
And then when the Sierra Madre loomed close, I just went left north and drove for about 40 miles on cow pads, basically, dodging cactus.
Took 12 hours to get them around that around roadblock.
So you're lucky the car didn't break down, for one.
It broke down on the other side of the border right after I took it across.
It had broken down out there, I don't know, it was a hundred like eight, 109 degrees - hot desert, 20 miles from anything.
I don't know, we could have died.
So you took this family.
It was a man, a woman and their small child.
Yes.
Their daughter, who was at that time two years old.
This was in 1984.
And as you write at the end of your essay in The New York Times, you get an e-mail from her.
Out of the blue I get this e-mail headlined Escape from El Salvador.
And it was Lil, the baby, writing me.
And at first I was excited.
I got to meet here.
And then it was like, I got nervous.
For a little while I didn't want to meet her.
Do I want to deal with this past?
I had to confront that.
And of course I ultimately of course did e-mail and meet with her and it was wonderful.
Well, we have her here now.
Lil Beatriz Calderon Huezo.
Welcome to the program.
How are you doing?
Fine, thank you.
So what moved you to write Dale and say hi after all these years?

My mom came to visit me in California from Michigan and she brought these like old newspapers - I guess they were like the originals - and they were written, you know, she just noticed that they were like Sacramento Bee and I moved to Sacramento.

She left them with me and then I read them and then I actually - I just Googled Dale's name and something popped up and so after a couple of days of just thinking I was like I'm just going to e-mail him.
And so you meet in this coffee shop, and what was it like?
Can you both tell me about that meeting?
I was really nervous.
I didn't know what to say.
And I was almost embarrassed.
You were embarrassed.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Yeah, almost embarrassed just because I didn't know how he felt, you know, whether he was just giving me the benefit of the doubt because it was something that, like, obviously means a lot to me.
I didn't realize that it was such an impact on him as well.
Dale?
I thought what if her life is a mess?
A lot of people I interviewed, you know, didn't end up so well.
But it turns out, you know, her life is great and Lil's a very happy young woman.
We had a delightful conversation.
So I was surprised.
But I was really nervous before she showed up too.
You are a journalism professor at Columbia.
I'm wondering what you would say to your students - or if they came up to you and said, you know what, I'm thinking of doing a similar thing.
You know, look, the kind of journalism that I do - I practice what I guess you would call immersion journalism.
When you do that, there's a risk that you get, you know, you kind of go native.
You know, you're into the story and you're part of the story.
But it's the only way to get that story.
I could have interviewed Salvadorans at the border and, you know, been - kept my little journalistic hat on.
But the journey that they went through I felt I needed to tell.
I don't recommend crossing the line.
I can't think of many other times in my life when I really crossed the line, but in this case it had to be done.
And if a young writer called me today with the exact same situation, I would probably counsel them to do the right thing, which is to help people first and be a journalist second.
Dale, why did you decide to write the story for the Times now?
I wasn't even thinking journalistically.
I was thinking like a human again.
I was like this is so wild.
This baby is calling me or e-mailing me.
And then after I met Lil I realized I did have to write about it because it was part of my, you know, dealing with the past.
I think it's a happy story out of so much darkness.
And it was a hard story to write.

It took me two-and-a-half weeks to write that little tiny story in the Times because all the demons and all the things that resurrected, to distil it down to that little story was very, very difficult.
Well, Dale, thank you very much.
Thank you, Madeleine.
And Lil, thank you.
Thanks.
That's Dale Maharidge and Lil Beatriz Calderon Huezo.
Their story is in this Sunday's New York Times Magazine.
I'm David Greene in Culver City, Calif., not far from where I met Viola Davis the other day.

The actress was working on her ABC show ""How To Get Away With Murder."" It was an insanely busy day of shooting, and yet she found some time to stop at her trailer to scarf down a salad and also meet with us.
Hi.
Hi.
Thank you for taking the time.
Viola Davis is known for movies like ""Fences"" and ""The Help."" She's won an Oscar, an Emmy, a couple Tonys for her stage performances.
But we were here to talk about a time before all of that, when she was growing up in a condemned building in Rhode Island.
She remembers sleeping on the top bunk with her sister to be safe from the rats on the floor.
She did have a way to transport herself away from all that.
Reading was the escape.
Reading was an escape into an imaginary world where none of those things existed, where I could I recreate myself and I could recreate a life where I played a better role.
And it's that place, in reading, it was that place that sort of saved me - going to the library every day after school when I was kindergarten, so 5 years old.
Who would take you every day?
By myself.
I would walk from Broad Street School to the library right after school, and I would stay there until it got dark and I would walk home.
At the Adams Library.
And they had a children's section downstairs, but I would stay upstairs for about five minutes because the head librarian would always save half her lunch for me.
And so I would eat the hell out of it, and then I'd go downstairs to the library where they had beanie bags and beautiful carpet and the smell of the books.
I just remember it like it was yesterday.
And that early love of reading has inspired a different kind of project for Viola Davis, this time off the screen.

She's written a sequel to the children's book ""Corduroy."" Fifty years ago, the author and illustrator Don Freeman brought us that story of a stuffed bear searching for the button that was missing from his overalls.
The book had something so many children's books lacked - diversity.
Corduroy's friend, Lisa, is black.
Viola Davis has always loved reading ""Corduroy"" to her 8-year-old daughter, Genesis.
I don't know what part she loved the best, the button on the overalls or Lisa and their friendship.
She loved that.
The night watchman in the department store.
It was every step of the way.
She was just in it.
So this book played a much larger role for you as a mom reading to your daughter than it did...
Yeah.
...For you as a child.
And I guess because with my daughter, I make up stories with her, too, at night.
And soon as I start a story, I'll say, Genesis, once upon a time.
She said, put me in a story, Mommy.
I want to be in the story.
And I think that's why ""Corduroy"" and writing this book has played such a large role because I want her to be included in the story.
I don't want her to have an experience like mine, which was I had to escape to be feeling like I was in the story.
I want her to actually feel a sense of worthiness.
That's what it is a sense of worthiness that's why I love ""Corduroy."" The fact that Lisa's African-American and her mom, it's her way of knowing that she's a part of something.
I want to talk a little bit about the story.

It's been, like, 50 years now since ""Corduroy"" first searched for the missing button, and so your book is called, ""Corduroy Takes A Bow."" Can you just tell our listeners where we find Corduroy now?
Corduroy gets lost in the theater.
Corduroy goes to the theater with Lisa...
The setting that's very meaningful to your life since you've done so much acting on stage.
We've been listening this morning to sounds of the presidential election in Afghanistan.
In Kandahar, some people voted despite reports of explosions.
In the remotest parts of the country, people voted on ballots that had to be delivered by donkey.
And there was also a gun battle reported in Kabul.
NPR's Jackie Northam visited several polling stations in Afghanistan's capital today.
She's on the line with us now.
Hi, Jackie.
Where are you?
Hi, Steve.
I'm actually at Zaruna(ph) High School.
It's a girl's school here in the center of Kabul.
We've been coming here throughout the day just to check on the size of the crowds that have developed in that - and really, I don't know if you could describe it as crowds.
First thing this morning when the polls opened at 7 AM, you know, there were a number of people here.
And I think everybody thought that as the day wore on and if there wasn't a security problem, that more and more people would come out.
But, in fact, just the opposite has happened.
Every time that we've come back during the day - we came at lunch hour.
There was nobody here except the election workers.
And I think if this is indicative of what's happening in other parts, it's got to be a disappointment.
But we really don't know how things are faring out throughout the rest of the country.
Well, Jackie, when you say turnout seems low - at least apparently, based on what you've seen - was this because people were concerned that security would not be adequate?
That appears to be the main reason.
You know, we've talked about this throughout the day.
The Afghan people - you know, I've been reporting here, as Renee Montagne has, as well.
And they were excited about these elections.
But there was this overriding fear that there were going to be attacks.
There was a gun battle today in Kabul, and some election officials say they think that that might have kept people away from this particular vote.
But you're at a point -there was a lot of security in this city today.
The police and the Afghan army were all over this city, as they were in other parts of the country, as well.
And there was a lot of security at the polling sites.
But that doesn't seem to have helped bring people out.
